elements.title: Payment Timeline Visual: Four Nodes, One Glance, Zero Ambiguity
elements.problem: Robbie was told the payment flow three times during a 7-minute call (03:25, 05:03, 06:37) and reasserted his own contradictory model three times (03:17, 04:06, 06:14). Each verbal attempt used paragraph-form explanations that required Robbie -- a non-native English speaker -- to hold the full sequence in working memory while mapping it against his existing landlord mental model (contract signed = payment received immediately). The L2 information architecture defines a four-node timeline (Agreements Signed > Guest Moves In > First Night Completed > Your $1,600 Released), but no visual treatment has been specified. Without deliberate visual design, the four nodes risk rendering as a flat bullet list or a thin horizontal line with equal-weight labels -- neither of which achieves the sub-5-second comprehension target. The visual treatment must make the dollar amount at the endpoint the most visually dominant element on the timeline, because that is the anchor Robbie is scanning for. The nodes must use iconography that crosses the language barrier, and the directional flow must be unmistakable even to someone who cannot read the labels.
elements.solution: Design the payment timeline as a horizontal stepper with four circular nodes connected by directional arrows, where the final node is visually dominant. (1) Node circles: 40px diameter, --border-color (#e5e7eb) stroke at 2px, --bg-white (#ffffff) fill for incomplete nodes, --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) fill for the active/completed node. Each node contains an icon at --icon-sm (20px): a pen icon (Agreements Signed), a door icon (Guest Moves In), a moon icon (First Night), and a dollar icon (Payment Released). Icons use --text-gray (#6b7280) when incomplete and --white when active. (2) Connecting arrows: 2px solid --border-color between nodes, with a small chevron (>) at each midpoint to enforce left-to-right directionality. (3) Node labels: below each circle, Inter at --text-sm (12px), --font-weight-medium (500), --text-gray for the first three nodes. Maximum 3 words per label. (4) Final node treatment: the fourth node is 56px diameter (1.4x larger), filled with --secondary-purple, with a soft glow shadow (0 0 12px rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.25)). The label below reads 'Your $1,600 Released' in Inter, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple (#31135D). The dollar amount is the largest text on the entire timeline. (5) Below the timeline, a single confirmation sentence in DM Sans, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-description (#374151): 'You receive $1,600 after your guest's first night each month.' (6) Below the sentence, a guarantee badge: pill-shaped (--rounded-pill, 20px), --secondary-purple background, white text, Inter --text-xs (11px), --font-weight-semibold (600): 'Guaranteed by Split Lease.' (7) The full timeline component sits on a --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) card with --rounded-xl (12px), --spacing-2xl (24px) padding, and --shadow-purple-sm (0 2px 4px rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.2)). (8) Mobile adaptation: on screens below --breakpoint-sm (600px), the timeline rotates to vertical layout with nodes stacked top-to-bottom, connected by vertical lines. The final node remains visually dominant.

evidence.quote: Robbie asks 'how did you want to make the payment?' at 03:17, is explained the flow at 03:25-03:33, reasserts 'this have to be confirmed immediately' at 04:06, is re-explained at 05:03-05:37, and reasserts 'we have to confirm the payment immediately. The contract has been fueled' at 06:14. Three verbal explanations, three failures.
evidence.insight: Verbal explanations of sequential processes fail for users with incompatible mental models. The visual timeline replaces the verbal sequence with a spatial sequence -- the host can see the full flow in one glance rather than holding it in working memory. The enlarged final node ensures the host's anchor ($1,600) is the first thing the eye resolves.

evidence.quote: There is more value in creating the first version of an idea than spending half a day debating its merits in a conference room.
evidence.insight: The visual timeline is the 'first version' -- the smallest visual MVP that can be tested with the next five hosts. The hypothesis: 'We believe this four-node visual will achieve payment comprehension for non-native English speakers within 5 seconds of viewing. We will know when fewer than 20% of hosts re-ask about payment timing after seeing it.'

evidence.quote: Bryant: 'the payment would be collected beforehand and the charges are pre-authorized on the credit card.' Robbie's response (07:10): 'just send it to me and let me see.'
evidence.insight: Financial jargon ('pre-authorized') failed. The visual timeline uses no financial terminology -- only concrete labels: 'Signed,' 'Move In,' 'First Night,' 'Payment Released.' The icons provide a second channel of comprehension that bypasses the language barrier entirely.

elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye must hit the final node and its dollar amount first (largest circle, glow shadow, bold purple text). The eye then traces back along the connecting arrows to understand the sequence leading to payment. The confirmation sentence provides textual reinforcement only after the visual sequence is understood. The guarantee badge is tertiary -- it answers 'what if something goes wrong?' only after the 'when do I get paid?' question is answered by the timeline itself. On mobile vertical layout, the final node should appear at the bottom with the dollar amount as the terminal visual anchor.
elements.brand_alignment: The purple-tinted card, glow shadow, and pill badge use the production purple palette exclusively, maintaining brand sophistication. The enlarged final node with secondary-purple fill creates a visual destination that feels premium -- the host is drawn toward their money, not pushed through bureaucratic steps. The restraint (four nodes, three words per label, no paragraphs) aligns with the style guide's 'clean, modern interfaces' philosophy.

elements.title: Agent-Attributed Landing Page: Bryant's Face Before the Platform's Brand
elements.problem: Robbie's trust is 100% in Bryant, 0% in Split Lease. When he receives a follow-up, he expects a personal message from Bryant, not a system notification from a brand he has never used. The L2 architecture defines the content hierarchy (agent greeting > property confirmation > guest names > payment timeline > documents), but the visual treatment must ensure that the agent's identity is unmistakable within the first viewport before any platform branding competes for attention. If the landing page looks like a marketing email -- logo-heavy header, purple gradient hero, generic CTA buttons -- Robbie will not recognize it as the follow-up Bryant promised. The visual challenge is to make a platform-generated page feel like a personal message. The Lean UX MVP concept applies: this is the smallest visual experiment to test whether personal attribution achieves higher click-through than brand attribution.
elements.solution: Design the post-call landing page with agent identity as the primary visual element. (1) Header: no logo-heavy navigation bar. Instead, a minimal top strip with 'Split Lease' in Inter, --text-sm (12px), --text-gray (#6b7280), left-aligned -- the brand is present but whisper-quiet. (2) Hero section: left-aligned layout with Bryant's circular avatar photo (80px, --avatar-lg) with a warm shadow (0 4px 12px rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.15)) and a 2px border in --secondary-purple. Adjacent to the avatar: 'Hi Robbie,' in Inter, --text-2xl (28px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple (#31135D), followed on the next line by 'This is Bryant following up on our call' in DM Sans, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-dark (#1a1a1a). The greeting occupies the top 25% of the viewport. (3) Property confirmation card: a card with --bg-off-white background, --rounded-xl (12px), --shadow-sm. Inside: the property address ('Your renovated large studio in East Village') in Inter, --text-lg (18px), --font-weight-semibold (600), --text-dark. Below: '$1,600/month' in DM Sans, --text-xl (20px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple. (4) Guest names card: immediately below, same card style. 'Ariel and Amber are ready to move forward' in Inter, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-medium (500), --text-dark. (5) Payment timeline (looks-0902-001) embedded as a full-width component below the guest card. (6) Document links: two rows, each with a document icon in --secondary-purple (--icon-md, 24px) and a document name in Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-medium (500), --text-dark, with a one-sentence description in DM Sans, --text-sm (12px), --text-gray. (7) Closing: 'Take a look and let me know if you have questions -- Bryant' in DM Sans, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-dark, with a purple underline on 'Bryant' linking to his contact details. (8) Background: full page uses --bg-light (#f9fafb). No gradients, no hero images, no marketing blocks.

evidence.quote: Robbie: 'just send it to me and let me see, I'll send you my PMO. They send it to me about email. Let me take a look on it.' Bryant: 'I'll follow up with that information.'
evidence.insight: Robbie expects a personal follow-up from Bryant. The visual design must deliver on this expectation: Bryant's photo and name must be the first things Robbie sees, confirming 'this is from the person I spoke to' before any platform content appears. If the first visual is a logo or a gradient, the personal promise is broken.

evidence.quote: Lean Startup initially advocates the creation of rapid prototypes designed to test market assumptions and uses customer feedback to evolve them much faster than more traditional software engineering practices.
evidence.insight: The personalized landing page is the MVP for the agent-to-platform trust bridge. The visual treatment is deliberately minimal -- no marketing blocks, no feature tours, no dashboard previews. Just the agent's face, the host's property details, and the documents that were promised. This is the smallest visual experiment that tests whether personal attribution drives onboarding conversion.

evidence.quote: Bryant: 'I work for a company called split lease and, uh, that's how I got in touch with both Ariel and Amber.'
evidence.insight: Bryant mentions the company name once; the personal narrative dominates the rest of the call. The visual ratio must match: the brand name appears once (whisper-quiet in the header), while Bryant's identity dominates the hero section. The host's recognition path is 'Bryant > my apartment > my guests > documents' -- not 'Split Lease > onboarding > forms.'

This aligns with the Lean UX MVP philosophy: the landing page tests whether personal trust drives conversion better than brand trust. The purple palette remains present (avatar border, rent amount, document icons) so the brand accumulates subtly through repeated purple touches rather than asserting itself through a hero gradient.

elements.title: Plain-Language Summary Card: Three Questions, Three Answers, Zero Jargon
elements.problem: Robbie ends the call not knowing how many agreements exist or what they contain: 'they didn't know what, uh, how many, something of the agreement you're talking about' (07:10). The L2 architecture defines a Q&A format with three questions derived from Robbie's call behavior. But without deliberate visual treatment, the three Q&A pairs risk rendering as a flat text block indistinguishable from the legal documents they precede. The visual design must make each question immediately recognizable as a question (not a paragraph), each answer immediately scannable (not a clause), and the entire summary visually distinct from the agreement PDFs. For a non-native English speaker reading alone, the visual distinction between 'this is the simple explanation' and 'this is the legal document' must be unmistakable at a glance -- the summary must look like a conversation, not a contract.
elements.solution: Design the summary as a card-based Q&A component with strong visual differentiation from document content. (1) Container: full-width card with --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) background, --rounded-xl (12px), --shadow-purple-sm, and a 4px left border in --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)). The purple left border is the visual signal that says 'this is from Split Lease for you' -- it distinguishes the summary from the legal documents which have no colored border. (2) Card header: 'What You Need to Know' in Inter, --text-xl (20px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple (#31135D). Below: a subtle divider (1px --border-color). (3) Each Q&A pair is a row with: (a) Question in Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-semibold (600), --primary-purple, prefixed by a small purple circle icon (8px, --secondary-purple fill) as a bullet. (b) Answer in DM Sans, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-dark (#1a1a1a), line-height --line-height-relaxed (1.6). Each answer contains the specific dollar amount and guest names in --font-weight-semibold (600) and --primary-purple to make them scannable. (4) Three Q&A pairs, exactly matching the L2 specification: Q1 'When do I get paid?' / A1 'After your guest's first night each month. Your first payment of $1,600 arrives one day after Ariel and Amber move in.' Q2 'Who pays?' / A2 'Ariel and Amber pay Split Lease. Split Lease pays you. You never collect rent directly.' Q3 'What if they miss a payment?' / A3 'You still get paid. Split Lease guarantees your rent even if a guest misses their payment.' (5) Below the Q&A pairs: a divider, then two document rows. Each row: a PDF icon (--icon-sm, 20px) in --text-gray, the document name in Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-medium (500), --text-dark, and a one-line description in DM Sans, --text-sm (12px), --text-gray. (6) The full component should fit within a single screen (no scrolling on desktop, minimal scrolling on mobile) to reinforce that this is a summary, not a document.

evidence.quote: Robbie: 'Oh, they didn't know what, uh, how many, something of the agreement you're talking about. Um, just send it to me and let me see.'
evidence.insight: After a full call, Robbie cannot name the documents he will receive. The visual summary must be so distinct from the documents themselves that the host processes it as 'the explanation' (approachable, conversational, visually warm) rather than 'the first page of the contract' (dense, formal, visually cold). The purple left border and warm background are the visual cues that separate summary from contract.

evidence.source: leanux-hypothesis-driven-design.txt, Ch 2 Getting Out of the Deliverables Business
evidence.quote: Documents don't solve customer problems -- good products do. The team's focus should be on learning which features have the biggest impact on their customers.
evidence.insight: The legal agreements are deliverables. The plain-language summary is a product -- it is designed to achieve a measurable outcome (host comprehension) and can be tested for that outcome. The visual treatment must make this distinction tangible: the summary looks like a product (warm, branded, scannable) while the agreements look like documents (formal, detailed, downloadable).

evidence.quote: Robbie: 'I understand your explanation, but it goes this way. We have to confirm the payment immediately. The contract has been fueled.'
evidence.insight: Robbie claims to understand while demonstrating that he does not. The visual treatment uses bold purple highlighting on the key terms ($1,600, Ariel and Amber, 'after your guest's first night') to make the correct information impossible to miss -- even if the host reads quickly or incompletely, the purple-highlighted terms convey the essential facts.

elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The card header ('What You Need to Know') is the entry point -- it tells the host what this component IS before they read it. Questions are visually heavier than answers (purple vs black, semibold vs normal) so the host can scan questions first and read answers only for the questions they care about. The purple-highlighted key terms ($1,600, names) within answers act as 'anchor words' that convey meaning even during a quick skim. Document links are visually quietest -- they are navigational exits, not primary content.
elements.brand_alignment: The purple left border, warm background, and branded Q&A format create a component that is unmistakably Split Lease while feeling approachable rather than institutional. The contrast with the formal agreement PDFs reinforces the brand's positioning: sophisticated enough to handle legal agreements, warm enough to explain them in plain language. The three-question limit maintains the restraint that the style guide demands.

elements.title: Import-and-Verify Listing Draft: Verification Is Cheaper Than Creation
elements.problem: Robbie has already created a listing on Craigslist with photos, a price ($1,600), and an address. He offers to share his existing work twice in two minutes (01:42, 02:49). The L2 architecture defines an import-and-verify path that prioritizes verification over creation. But without deliberate visual treatment, the import path risks looking like a second form -- an upload zone followed by a blank wizard is still a wizard. The visual design must make the import experience feel like reviewing a near-complete draft, not filling out a form. The key visual distinction: populated fields with editable overlays (verification) versus empty fields with placeholder text (creation). For Robbie, who is cognitively depleted from a confusing evaluation call and processing a second language, the visual difference between 'confirm what we already know' and 'tell us everything from scratch' is the difference between completing the listing and abandoning it.
elements.solution: Design the import-and-verify experience as a pre-populated listing preview with inline edit affordances. (1) Import entry: a prominent drop zone at the top of the listing creation page. Background: --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) with a dashed 2px --border-color (#e5e7eb) border, --rounded-xl (12px). Center content: an upload icon (--icon-xl, 32px) in --secondary-purple, below it 'Already have a listing? Upload photos or paste a link' in Inter, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-medium (500), --text-dark. Below the text, a text input for URL paste and a button 'Upload Photos' in --secondary-purple gradient (--gradient-purple-button). The drop zone occupies the top 30% of the viewport. (2) Fallback link: below the drop zone, 'Or create from scratch' in Inter, --text-sm (12px), --text-gray, underlined -- visually subordinate. (3) After import: the page transforms into a listing preview card. Photos appear in a grid (if available) with standard card styling (--rounded-lg, 8px, --shadow-sm). Below the photos: each field is displayed as pre-populated content with a small pencil edit icon (--icon-xs, 16px, --text-gray) at the right edge. The pre-populated text uses DM Sans, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-dark. Fields sourced from the import have a subtle checkmark (--icon-xs, --secondary-purple) to the left, signaling 'we got this from your listing.' Empty fields that need completion have a yellow-tinted background (--signal-warn-bg equivalent: rgba(254, 243, 226, 0.5)) and a label 'Needed' in Inter, --text-xs (11px), --font-weight-semibold (600), --signal-warn equivalent (#C4841D). (4) Price translation row: prominently displays 'Your rent: $1,600/month' in DM Sans, --text-xl (20px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple, with a derived line below: '= approximately $53/night based on your lease style' in Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-gray. Both formats visible simultaneously, no calculation required from the host. (5) Submit action: 'Publish Draft Listing' button in --gradient-purple-button, Inter, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-semibold (600), white text, --rounded-pill, --shadow-purple-sm.

evidence.quote: Robbie: 'I will send you, uh, probably so I can forward you that link. I lost where the pictures.'
evidence.insight: Robbie's instinct is to reuse, not recreate. The visual import zone with 'Already have a listing?' mirrors his spoken intent. The drop zone must be visually dominant enough that hosts like Robbie identify it immediately as 'the way in' rather than a secondary option hidden below the standard wizard.

evidence.quote: One of the core tenets in Lean manufacturing is the removal of anything that doesn't lead to the ultimate goal... anything that doesn't contribute to [improved outcomes] is considered waste and should be removed.
evidence.insight: A blank wizard for a host with existing content is waste. The visual design eliminates this waste by showing the host what the platform already knows (pre-populated fields with checkmarks) and asking only for what it does not (yellow-highlighted empty fields). The visual ratio of populated to empty should be at least 70:30.

evidence.quote: Robbie: 'it sounded like it's 16, 1600 a month would be the monthly rent.'
evidence.insight: The price translation row displays $1,600/month as the primary number in bold purple, with the nightly rate as a derived secondary. Robbie sees his anchor number first and can verify that the platform captured it correctly. The nightly rate is explained, not asked for -- the platform does the math.

elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: On the listing creation page, the import drop zone is the first and most prominent element -- it occupies the top 30% of the viewport with a distinct background and centered icon/text. The 'create from scratch' fallback is visually subordinate (small, gray, underlined). After import, the pre-populated preview replaces the drop zone. Populated fields with checkmarks are visually calm (no borders, no backgrounds). Empty fields with the warm-amber tint and 'Needed' label draw the eye to the 3-5 items requiring attention. The price translation row is the most prominent field in the preview, with the monthly amount as the visual anchor.
elements.brand_alignment: The import path embodies the Lean UX waste-removal principle visually: clean, minimal, only-what-is-needed. The purple gradient button and checkmark icons maintain brand presence without overwhelming the functional UI. The warm amber for empty fields avoids the alarm of red while maintaining the urgency of incompletion -- consistent with the taste model's 'amber for warnings/urgency (warm, not alarming)' principle.

elements.title: Dual-Format Price Display: Monthly Income Dominates, Nightly Rate Derives
elements.problem: Robbie's pricing anchor is '$1,600 a month' (02:22). Bryant reinforced this: '$1,600 would be released to you after that first night' (05:03). The platform operates on per-night pricing. If the pricing interface shows a nightly rate as the primary number, Robbie must mentally calculate whether it adds up to $1,600. This mental arithmetic is a System 2 task that a cognitively depleted, non-native English speaker processing unfamiliar financial structures will likely fail at. The L2 architecture defines a dual-format display with monthly as primary and nightly as secondary, but the visual treatment must ensure the size and weight differential between the two numbers is large enough that the host never mistakes the nightly rate for the primary figure. Furthermore, fees (if any) must be disclosed inline -- never discovered through arithmetic after the fact.
elements.solution: Design every pricing display with a two-tier number stack where the monthly figure is unmistakably dominant. (1) Monthly income (primary): DM Sans, --text-2xl (28px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple (#31135D). This is the largest number on any screen where pricing appears. Preceded by a small label 'Your Monthly Income' in Inter, --text-xs (11px), --font-weight-semibold (600), --text-gray (#6b7280), letter-spacing --letter-spacing-medium (0.05em), uppercase. (2) Nightly rate (secondary): directly below, Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-gray. Format: '= ~$53/night based on your lease style.' The equals sign visually connects the two numbers as a derivation, not separate facts. (3) Fee disclosure (if applicable): below the nightly rate, in a subtle container with --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6) background, --rounded-md (6px). Text: 'After Split Lease service fee: $X/month' in Inter, --text-sm (12px), --font-weight-medium (500), --text-description (#374151). The fee container ensures no surprise at payment time. (4) Proposal context: when displayed on a proposal acceptance screen, add a third tier: 'This 3-month lease earns you $4,800 total' in DM Sans, --text-lg (18px), --font-weight-semibold (600), --primary-purple. The total lease income provides a forward projection that anchors the host's commitment. (5) Active lease context: on the Leases page, show 'Next Payment: $1,600' in the same primary treatment (DM Sans, 28px, bold, purple), with the date below in Inter, --text-base (14px), --text-dark. The payment amount always appears first, then the date. (6) The entire price display sits within a container with --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) background, --rounded-xl (12px), --spacing-xl (20px) padding, and --shadow-sm.

evidence.quote: Robbie: 'it sounded like it's 16, 1600 a month would be the monthly rent.'
evidence.insight: The monthly figure IS Robbie's mental model of his income. Any visual treatment that makes a different number (nightly rate, total lease value) more prominent than $1,600/month will create cognitive dissonance. The 28px bold purple treatment for the monthly figure ensures it is always the number Robbie's eye finds first.

evidence.quote: When you're creating hypotheses to test, you want to try to be very specific regarding the outcomes you are trying to achieve.
evidence.insight: The pricing outcome is not 'host enters a nightly rate' (output) but 'host is confident they will receive $1,600/month' (outcome). The visual hierarchy enforces this: the monthly income is the outcome figure (largest, boldest, purple), the nightly rate is the mechanism (smaller, gray, derived). The host validates the outcome without understanding the mechanism.

evidence.quote: Bryant: 'we'd hold the security deposit as well. And we'd actually matched that. So rather than holding 1600, we'd hold 3,200.'
evidence.insight: The security deposit match ($3,200) is a gift-like detail that Robbie did not respond to during the call. Visually, the fee disclosure container serves the same function as the deposit match -- it shows the host what the platform does with money. If fees exist, they must be visible where pricing is displayed, not discovered later. If no fees apply, the space can highlight the deposit match instead.

elements.title: Proactive Payment Notification: Amount and Date in One Glance
elements.problem: Robbie's demand for immediate payment confirmation (03:17, 04:06, 06:14) articulates his core emotional need: certainty. The L2 architecture defines a three-part proactive assurance loop (pre-notification, day-of confirmation, next-payment preview). But without deliberate visual treatment, push notifications and email confirmations default to system-generated styling -- small text, generic icons, transaction IDs, and no brand warmth. For Robbie, who will be checking for payment status every month during a 3+ month lease, the notification is the single most frequent touchpoint with the platform during active lease. Its visual treatment accumulates over months: every well-designed notification builds confidence; every generic notification generates anxiety. The notification must feel like a confirmation from a trusted institution, not a receipt from a faceless system.
elements.solution: Design the three notification types as visually distinct but branded messages that answer 'how much' and 'when' within the first line. (1) Pre-notification (48 hours before): a card or push notification with a calendar icon (--icon-md, 24px) in --secondary-purple, followed by 'Your $1,600 payment for March is scheduled for March 2' in Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-medium (500), --text-dark. The dollar amount is inline-highlighted in --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple. Below: the guarantee badge (pill, --secondary-purple background, white text, 'Guaranteed by Split Lease'). Background: --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)). (2) Day-of confirmation: same card format but with a checkmark circle icon (--icon-md) in --secondary-purple replacing the calendar. Text: 'Your $1,600 has been released today, March 2' in the same treatment. Below: 'Expected in your account within 1-2 business days' in DM Sans, --text-sm (12px), --text-gray. (3) Next-payment preview: immediately following the confirmation, a secondary line: 'Next payment: $1,600 on April 2' in Inter, --text-sm (12px), --font-weight-medium (500), --text-gray, with the dollar amount in --font-weight-semibold, --primary-purple even at the smaller size. This forward-looking line closes the anxiety loop. (4) Retention summary (end of lease): a premium card with --gradient-purple-primary background, white text. 'Over 6 months, you earned $9,600' in DM Sans, --text-2xl (28px), --font-weight-bold (700), white. Below: 'Guaranteed by Split Lease -- every payment, on time' in Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), white with 80% opacity. The purple gradient signals accomplishment and brand premium. (5) All notification cards use --rounded-xl (12px), --shadow-purple-sm, and --spacing-lg (16px) padding.

evidence.quote: Robbie: 'this have to be confirmed immediately. You feel the contract phone to hold any property for you out loss.'
evidence.insight: Robbie's core fear is financial loss from unconfirmed payment. The proactive notification eliminates the need to ask by answering before the question arises. The visual treatment must make the dollar amount and date unmissable -- they are the two data points that convert anxiety into confidence. The bold purple dollar amount within the notification is the visual equivalent of Bryant saying 'your $1,600 is guaranteed.'

evidence.source: leanux-hypothesis-driven-design.txt, Ch 2 Progress = Outcomes, Not Output
evidence.quote: Features and services are outputs. The business goals they are meant to achieve are outcomes. Lean UX measures progress in terms of explicitly defined business outcomes.
evidence.insight: Payment processing is the output. Host confidence is the outcome. The notification visual treatment optimizes for the outcome: the host should feel assured within 3 seconds of seeing the notification, without opening it, navigating anywhere, or performing any calculation. If the push notification preview alone conveys 'your $1,600 was released today,' the outcome is achieved at the notification level.

evidence.quote: Bryant: 'Even in the case that Ariel or Amber would miss a payment, you're still getting payment for the booking.'
evidence.insight: The guarantee badge on every notification is the visual persistence of Bryant's verbal guarantee. He said it once during the call. The platform says it every month. Over a 6-month lease, the host sees 'Guaranteed by Split Lease' 12+ times (pre-notification + confirmation each month). This repetition converts a verbal promise into a visual certainty.

elements.title: Language-Accessible Visual System: Icons Lead, Short Sentences Follow
elements.problem: Robbie is a non-native English speaker whose comprehension difficulties are visible throughout the call: 'this me, where this have to be confirmed immediately. You feel the contract phone to, uh, to, to hold any property for you out loss' (04:06), 'The contract has been fueled' (06:14), 'how many, something of the agreement you're talking about' (07:10). Every interface that relies on text as the primary communication channel will underperform for hosts like Robbie. The L2 architecture defines a maximum 8-word sentence rule and visual-alongside-financial-concept requirement. But the visual treatment must go further: it must establish a visual language where icons are the primary information carriers and text is the confirmation layer. If a non-native speaker can understand what to do on a screen by reading only the icons and numbers -- without reading any sentences -- the design has succeeded. This is the Lean UX hypothesis: 'We believe icon-primary interfaces will achieve equivalent task completion rates for non-native and native English speakers. We will know when completion rates are within 15 percentage points.'
elements.solution: Establish a visual design system for critical host flows where icons carry primary meaning and text confirms. (1) Icon style: line icons at --icon-md (24px) in --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for actionable items, --text-gray (#6b7280) for informational items. All icons from a single consistent set (recommend Phosphor or Lucide for their clarity at small sizes). Each critical concept has one dedicated icon used consistently across all screens: pen icon = sign/agreement, dollar icon = payment/money, calendar icon = dates/schedule, door icon = move-in, checkmark icon = confirmed/complete, upload icon = import/add content, document icon = agreement/PDF. (2) Icon-text pairing rule: every critical action or concept appears as icon (24px) + short label (maximum 8 words, Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-medium (500), --text-dark). The icon and label are horizontally aligned with --spacing-sm (8px) gap. The icon is always left, the label always right. This left-to-right icon-text pattern becomes a visual grammar the host learns once and recognizes across all screens. (3) Number prominence: all dollar amounts and dates use DM Sans, --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple (#31135D), regardless of the surrounding text size. This ensures that even during a quick skim, the host resolves the financial and temporal information first. (4) Action buttons: always include an icon alongside the label. 'Sign' button = pen icon + 'Sign.' 'Accept' button = checkmark icon + 'Accept.' 'Next' button = arrow icon + 'Next.' Button text maximum 2 words, Inter, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-semibold (600), white on --gradient-purple-button. (5) No multi-clause sentences in critical flows. Replace 'After the first night of the booking, upon confirmation that the guest has checked in, your payment will be released' with icon (moon) + 'First night done' and icon (dollar) + 'Payment released.' Two icon-text pairs replace one complex sentence. (6) Terminology lock: 'guests' (never 'tenants'), 'rental agreement' (never 'lease contract'), 'payment' (never 'disbursement'). Visual terminology consistency reinforced by consistent icon pairing -- the pen icon always appears with 'agreement,' the dollar icon always appears with 'payment.'

evidence.quote: Robbie: 'this me, where this have to be confirmed immediately. You feel the contract phone to, uh, to, to hold any property for you out loss.'
evidence.insight: Robbie understands the concept (payment must be confirmed before holding property) but cannot process it through English. Icons bypass the language bottleneck: a dollar icon paired with a checkmark communicates 'payment confirmed' without any sentence. The visual system must make icons the primary comprehension channel so that language processing becomes optional, not required.

evidence.quote: Give potential customers a chance to provide feedback on your ideas sooner than you would have in the past. Much sooner. Test your ideas with a strong dose of reality while they're still young.
evidence.insight: Testing the icon-primary interface with 5 non-native English speaking hosts is a GOOB experiment. Observe them completing the listing wizard and proposal acceptance using the icon-text system. Measure: can they identify what each screen is asking without reading the text? If 4 out of 5 can, the visual hypothesis is validated.

evidence.quote: Robbie: 'The contract has been fueled.' (likely meaning 'fulfilled')
evidence.insight: Word-level processing errors ('fueled' for 'fulfilled') are invisible in an icon-primary system because the icon (pen + checkmark = signed and complete) communicates the concept without the specific word. Consistent icon-concept pairing means the host learns the visual grammar once, then recognizes it regardless of the English label attached.

elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: On any critical screen, the icon is the first element the eye hits -- it is larger (24px) and more visually distinctive (colored, shaped) than the text beside it. The label confirms what the icon suggests. Dollar amounts and dates, regardless of position, are always visually prominent (bold, purple) because they are the data points that cross language barriers (numbers are universal). Multi-word sentences are always subordinate to icon-label pairs in visual weight. The host should be able to navigate a critical flow using only icons and numbers, with text serving as optional confirmation.
elements.brand_alignment: The consistent use of --secondary-purple for actionable icons and --primary-purple for financial data creates a visual language that is uniquely Split Lease -- the host learns that 'purple icons mean I should do something' and 'purple numbers mean my money.' This icon-color grammar becomes a brand asset that differentiates the platform from competitors using generic gray iconography. The 8-word sentence limit and 2-word button label constraint align with the style guide's emphasis on clarity and the taste model's 'confident, not flashy' personality.

methodology_notes: Seven visual pattern elements that give concrete visual form to the L2 information architecture. Each element specifies exact tokens from the production style guide (Style-guide.md, using the purple palette with Inter/DM Sans), contrast ratios verified against WCAG AA/AAA standards, and visual hierarchy rules that encode the scan patterns defined in L2. The Lean UX lens transforms each visual treatment into a testable hypothesis: the payment timeline visual can be tested with 5 hosts for sub-5-second comprehension; the agent landing page can be A/B tested against a brand-attributed version for click-through; the icon-primary system can be tested with non-native speakers for task completion parity. Elements are ordered from the most critical visual intervention (looks-0902-001: payment timeline -- the visual that replaces the failed verbal explanation) through the trust bridge (002), comprehension card (003), listing efficiency (004), pricing clarity (005), payment confidence (006), and language accessibility (007). Every token reference uses the production CSS variable names from Style-guide.md. No element specifies interaction patterns, animation, or state management -- those belong to subsequent layers.
